body.p: According to the official M&M website, 24% of the plain milk chocolate M&Mâ€™s produced by Mars Corporation are blue. Annie buys a large family-size bag of M&M's. Sarah buys a small fun-size bag. Which bag is more likely to have more than 40% blue M&M's?

multiple_choice.choice: Annie, because there are more M&M's in her bag, so she will have more blue ones.
Annie, because there is more variability in the proportion of blues among larger samples.
Sarah, because there is more variability in the proportion of blues among smaller samples.
Both have the same chance because they are both random samples.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is true that a larger bag will have more blue candies, there are also more candies in the bag. We are interested in the proportion that are blue.
Incorrect. There will be less variability in large samples.
Correct. There is more variability in small samples, so it is more likely to get sample results further from p = 0.24 with a small bag.
Incorrect. In random sampling, the size of the sample impacts the variability in the sample results.

part.hint: Think about the spread of the sampling distribution around p = 0.24. For which size of bag will sample proportions greater than 0.40 be more common?

If p-hats greater than 0.40 occur frequently, the sampling distribution has a large spread around p = 0.24. In the sampling distribution, will we see more variability when using a large sample size or a small sample size?
